docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Iraqi Leader Arrives in U.S. With a Nationalist Agenda Ahmad Chalabi, the president of Iraq's interim government and once a protégé of Pentagon conservatives, said the Iraqi Governing Council should be given at least partial control of the financial and security ministries, and rejected the idea of more foreign troops coming to Iraq. A1 L. Paul Bremer III, the American administrator in Iraq, defended the Bush administration's request for $87 billion on Capitol Hill, saying that without the aid, Iraq would become a global menace. A12

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST May, Dave DeBusschere, the former New York Knicks star, collapsed and died from a heart attack at age 62 while walking to lunch in Lower Manhattan. Subsequent reports described him as having appeared fit. An article in The New York Times said that the 6-foot-6 Mr. DeBusschere was ''not much over his playing weight of 235 pounds'' and had ''no apparent symptoms of ill health.'' Coronary heart disease is the leading cause of death among American men, claiming more than 260,000 lives each year. According to the Framingham Heart Study of the National Institutes of Health, nearly half of all coronary deaths affect people, like Dave DeBusschere, with no history of heart disease symptoms. For them, a fatal heart attack or sudden death is the first and last hint of a problem.

headline.main: It's Good in Your Bones, Bad in Your Arteries

docs.abstract: Coronary heart disease is leading cause of death among American men, claiming more than 260,000 lives each year; study finds nearly half of all coronary deaths affect people with no history of heart disease symptoms; one approach to finding disease at treatable stage is test that detects calcium deposits in walls of coronary arteries; so-called calcium heart scanning has been drawing increasing attention; it is noninvasive and painless, but also controversial because of heated debate over value of body scanning in general; test described; photo (Special section, Men & Health) (M)
